```[    8s] ______________________ test_settings_path_skip_issue_909 _______________________
[    8s]                         for fd in [p2cread, c2pwrite, errwrite]:
[    8s]                             if fd not in closed and fd > 2:
[    8s]                                 os.close(fd)
[    8s]                                 closed.add(fd)
[    8s]     
[    8s]                         if cwd is not None:
[    8s]                             os.chdir(cwd)
[    8s]     
[    8s]                         if preexec_fn:
[    8s]                             preexec_fn()
[    8s]     
[    8s]                         # Close all other fds, if asked for - after
[    8s]                         # preexec_fn(), which may open FDs.
[    8s]                         if close_fds:
[    8s]                             self._close_fds(but=errpipe_write)
[    8s]     
[    8s]                         if env is None:
[    8s]                             os.execvp(executable, args)
[    8s]                         else:
[    8s]                             os.execvpe(executable, args, env)
[    8s]     
[    8s]                     except:
[    8s]                         exc_type, exc_value, tb = sys.exc_info()
[    8s]                         # Save the traceback and attach it to the exception object
[    8s]                         exc_lines = traceback.format_exception(exc_type,
[    8s]                                                                exc_value,
[    8s]                                                                tb)
[    8s]                         exc_value.child_traceback = ''.join(exc_lines)
[    8s]                         os.write(errpipe_write, pickle.dumps(exc_value))
[    8s]     
[    8s]                     finally:
[    8s]                         # This exitcode won't be reported to applications, so it
[    8s]                         # really doesn't matter what we return.
[    8s]                         os._exit(255)
[    8s]     
[    8s]                 # Parent
[    8s]                 if gc_was_enabled:
[    8s]                     gc.enable()
[    8s]             finally:
[    8s]                 # be sure the FD is closed no matter what
[    8s]                 os.close(errpipe_write)
[    8s]     
[    8s]             # Wait for exec to fail or succeed; possibly raising exception
[    8s]             data = _eintr_retry_call(os.read, errpipe_read, 1048576)
[    8s]             pickle_bits = []
[    8s]             while data:
[    8s]                 pickle_bits.append(data)
[    8s]                 data = _eintr_retry_call(os.read, errpipe_read, 1048576)
[    8s]             data = "".join(pickle_bits)
[    8s]         finally:
[    8s]             if p2cread is not None and p2cwrite is not None:
[    8s]                 _close_in_parent(p2cread)
[    8s]             if c2pwrite is not None and c2pread is not None:
[    8s]                 _close_in_parent(c2pwrite)
[    8s]             if errwrite is not None and errread is not None:
[    8s]                 _close_in_parent(errwrite)
[    8s]     
[    8s]             # be sure the FD is closed no matter what
[    8s]             os.close(errpipe_read)
[    8s]     
[    8s]         if data != "":
[    8s]             try:
[    8s]                 _eintr_retry_call(os.waitpid, self.pid, 0)
[    8s]             except OSError as e:

[    8s]                     raise
[    8s]             child_exception = pickle.loads(data)
[    8s] >           raise child_exception
```

title: skip and skip-glob are not enforced when using settings-path
body:
Hi,

Version used: 4.3.15, not tested on other versions.

Setup:
```console
$ tree -a
.
├── conf
│   └── .isort.cfg
├── file_glob_skip.py
└── file_to_be_skipped.py

1 directory, 3 files
$ cat conf/.isort.cfg 
[isort]
skip =
    file_to_be_skipped.py
skip_glob =
    *glob_skip*
$ cat file_glob_skip.py 
import os

print("Hello World")

import sys
$ cat file_to_be_skipped.py 
import os

print("Hello World")

import sys
```

Files are not skipped when using `--settings-path=conf/.isort.cfg`:
```console
$ isort --check-only --settings-path=conf/.isort.cfg
ERROR: /home/romain/Area51/isort_skip_bug/file_glob_skip.py Imports are incorrectly sorted.
ERROR: /home/romain/Area51/isort_skip_bug/file_to_be_skipped.py Imports are incorrectly sorted.
```
But works when using CLI options:
```console
$ isort --check-only --skip file_to_be_skipped.py --skip-glob '*glob_skip*' 
Skipped 2 files
```

The problem seems to have two causes:
1.  `check_skip` is _always_ set to `False` [1] which make `SortImports` not even trying any of the skip options [2] while the class use `True` as default for that argument [3]
2. Options defined in a settings-path file are not used [4] by `iter_source_code()` [5], the `config` dict will only contain options a local `.isort.cfg` and CLI options.

[1] https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.15/isort/main.py#L320
[2] https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.15/isort/isort.py#L98
[3] https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.15/isort/isort.py#L51
[4] https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.15/isort/main.py#L348-L349
[5] https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.15/isort/main.py#L353

A bisect give me 91ae94e477d066f133a889d13f3bd25363785258 as first bad commit.

title: The position of the import heading is somtimes strange.
body:
I use 4.3.15 version of isort.

The location of the import heading in the example below is a bit strange.

```python
from isort import SortImports


text_old = """# Third party imports
import numpy as np

# Local imports
from oklib.plot_ok import imagesc

import os.path as osp
"""

config = {'import_heading_stdlib': 'Standard library imports',
          'import_heading_thirdparty': 'Third party imports',
          'import_heading_firstparty': 'Local imports'}

new_contents = SortImports(file_contents=text_old, **config).output
print(new_contents)

```

The result of the example is as follows.
```python
# Third party imports
# Standard library imports
import os.path as osp

import numpy as np

# Local imports
from oklib.plot_ok import imagesc
```

The expected results are as follows.
```python
# Standard library imports
import os.path as osp

# Third party imports
import numpy as np

# Local imports
from oklib.plot_ok import imagesc
```

Thanks for reading. Have a nice day.

```python
import os
```

title: isort does not skip files
body:
**Describe the bug**

`isort` does not respect `skip` and `skip_glob` configuration options.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Create `file.py` with the following content:
    ```python
    import os, \
        sys
    ```
2. Create `.isort.cfg` with the following content:
    ```
    [settings]
    skip_glob = file.py
    ```
3. Run `isort file.py`.
4. Open `file.py` and check out it's content to become:
    ```python
    import os
    import sys
    ```

**Expected behavior**

A `file.py` is skipped and is not touched.

**Screenshots**

—

**Environment (please complete the following information):**

- OS: Linux
- Python version: 3.7.2
- isort version: 4.3.11

**Additional context**

`isort` 4.3.10 is working correctly. Issue can be reproduced with `skip` option as well.

title: confused by symlinks pointing to virtualenv gives FIRSTPARTY not THIRDPARTY
body:
On my box using isort 4.3.10

```
lrwxrwxrwx 1 brian brian 36 Aug  8  2018 /home/brian/.virtualenvs -> /home/brian/.local/share/virtualenvs
```

This appears to get isort confused, and it can incorrectly categorize third party imports as first party.

```
from-type place_module for django_cron returned FIRSTPARTY
```

If I redo with another virtual environment that doesn't have symlinks it shows:

```
from-type place_module for django_cron returned THIRDPARTY
```

Which I believe is correct.

I believe it is failing here: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/f6ff653fbf149b67cef1e553940b788a9afa685e/isort/finders.py#L176

Where `self.virtual_env_src` contains `/home/brian/.virtualenvs/energy_rating/src/` and `prefix` contains `
/home/brian/.local/share/virtualenvs/energy_rating/src/django-cron`

I suspect the solution might be to apply `os.path.realpath()` on `self.virtual_env_src`, which would turn it into `/home/brian/.local/share/virtualenvs/energy_rating/src` and the condition will pass.

title: Current version skips every file on Travis
body:
This PR #810 added a new check to skip some files/directories considered unsafe by default.

The regex excludes anything with `build` in the path, which usually would be ok.

However, Travis does its job by cloning to `/home/travis/build/`.

This effectively causes every file to be skipped by isort when running on Travis by default.

Using `--unsafe` or `safety_excludes=False` in the config solves the issue.

title: Parameter install_requires (for futures) removed in 4.3.7 but now back in 4.3.9
body:
There used to be a conditional dependency on the `futures` package that was removed in `isort 4.3.7` but it is now back in `isort 4.3.9`. Is this intentional?

Here is a detailed description of this observation along with links to source code:

  - `isort 4.3.6` has `install_requires=['futures; python_version < "3.2"']` in its `setup.py` ([source][dep 4.3.6]).
  - `isort 4.3.7` does not have `install_requires` in its `setup.py` ([source][dep 4.3.7]).
  - `isort 4.3.8` does not have `install_requires` in its `setup.py` ([source][dep 4.3.8]).
  - `isort 4.3.9` has `install_requires=['futures; python_version < "3.2"']` in its `setup.py` ([source][dep 4.3.9]).

Note: Tags [4.3.7][tag 4.3.7] and [4.3.8][tag 4.3.8] point to the same commit, i.e., commit 7b129bd.

The dependency on `futures` was first removed in commit 3c54c0e: **Make isort run with Python 3 only** ([source][diff]). This commit is present in `develop` but not in `master`.

```
$ git branch --contains 3c54c0e
  develop

$ git merge-base --is-ancestor 3c54c0e develop && echo true || echo false
true

$ git merge-base --is-ancestor 3c54c0e master && echo true || echo false
false
```

Further, this commit was first released in version 4.3.7 but now missing from 4.3.9.

```
$ git merge-base --is-ancestor 3c54c0e 4.3.6 && echo true || echo false
false

$ git merge-base --is-ancestor 3c54c0e 4.3.7 && echo true || echo false
true

$ git merge-base --is-ancestor 3c54c0e 4.3.8 && echo true || echo false
true

$ git merge-base --is-ancestor 3c54c0e 4.3.9 && echo true || echo false
false
```

It has gone missing from 4.3.9 because while 4.3.7 and 4.3.8 were released from `develop` which did have this commit, 4.3.9 was released from `master` which does not have this commit.

```
$ git branch --contains 4.3.7
  develop

$ git branch --contains 4.3.8
  develop

$ git branch --contains 4.3.9
* master

$ git merge-base --is-ancestor 4.3.7 4.3.9 && echo true || echo false
false
```

Generally, one would expect a recent release to contain the commits of earlier releases, but the most recent release, 4.3.9, does not contain the commits of 4.3.7. As a result the commit titled **Make isort run with Python 3 only** which was present in 4.3.7 is no longer present in 4.3.9. Is this intentional?

Reference: I found this while investigating a build failure in cloudmarker/cloudmarker#45. While this is technically not an issue in `isort` and the issue is due to an old version of `setuptools` not handling the dependency `futures; python_version < "3.2"` properly, I still want to check with you if this dependency was brought back into 4.3.9 intentionally.

[dep 4.3.6]: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.6/setup.py#L30
[dep 4.3.8]: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.7/setup.py#L30
[dep 4.3.7]: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.8/setup.py#L30
[dep 4.3.9]: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/4.3.9/setup.py#L30

[tag 4.3.7]: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/commits/4.3.7
[tag 4.3.8]: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/commits/4.3.8
[tag 4.3.9]: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/commits/4.3.9

[diff]: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/commit/3c54c0e4177b2c92db40161a83397f1b221de57d#diff-2eeaed663bd0d25b7e608891384b7298L29

title: pie_slice in isort>=4.3.5 no longer sets sys.setdefaultencoding('utf-8')
body:
Hi! We're experiencing a new error in a Python 2.7 lint test that I believe was caused by bumping our isort from 4.3.4 to 4.3.5 (by way of flake8-isort's call to SortImports with both `file_path` and `file_contents`).

I see that the 4.3.5 version of pie_slice.py no longer calls `sys.setdefaultencoding('utf-8')` in python 2; which means source code containing non-ASCII now errors with `UnicodeDecodeError` on [line 129 of isort.py](https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/blob/a7007483856e0f06c9cfe715a335d22936e3b3c9/isort/isort.py#L129). In general, IIUC, it seems `file_contents` cannot be a string with non-ASCII characters.

Wondering what you think would be the best resolution for this issue? And thank you so much for the great tool all these years!

title: Wrong indentation with .editorconfig
body:
isort seems to have problems parsing an `.editorconfig` file with overrides.

If the file looks like the following:

```
root = true

[*]
charset = utf-8
end_of_line = lf
indent_size = 2
indent_style = tab
insert_final_newline = true
trim_trailing_whitespace = true

[*.{py,rst}]
indent_size = 4
indent_style = space
```

isort will indent my multiline imports (`multi_line_output = 3`) with 2 tabs instead of 4 spaces. It seems to be using the wildcard configuration instead of the Python configuration which should override it.

title: ISort fails to recognise whitespace-only line as a blank line
body:
When processing lines, ISort fails to recognise some whitespace-only lines as blank lines.

[isort-blank-lines.py.txt](https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/files/2798880/isort-blank-lines.py.txt)
The attached file contains this content:

```python
    import os
    import sys

     
    print("Hello, world!")
```

When ISort process that input file, the two blank lines are not recognised correctly, and ISort mandates these changes:

```
    $ python3 -m isort --check-only --diff ./isort-blank-lines.py 
    ERROR: /home/bignose/Projects/python/isort-blank-lines.py Imports are incorrectly sorted.
    --- /home/bignose/Projects/python/isort-blank-lines.py:before   2019-01-26 21:14:47.421581
    +++ /home/bignose/Projects/python/isort-blank-lines.py:after    2019-01-26 21:15:18.837737
    @@ -1,6 +1,4 @@
     import os
     import sys
     
    --
     print("Hello, world!")
```

The input file is valid, because the second blank line (containing only U+000C FORM FEED) is a valid blank line in Python code.

ISort should use the same meaning of “blank line” as the Python compiler.

title: no_sections moves __futures__ import to the bottom
body:
Trying to isort this:

```python
from __future__ import print_function
import os
```

with `no_sections` results in this:

```python
import os
from __future__ import print_function
```

However, `__future__` imports should always be at the top.

title: isort chokes on fifo
body:
If there is a fifo in the directory tree, isort stops responding.

Steps to reproduce (on linux):
```
isort
# verify that the run completes
mkfifo myfifo
isort
# observe that the run never completes
```

Presumably it opens the fifo and attempts to read, thus waiting for input which is never coming.
I recommend that isort ignores fifo by default.

title: 'user' is not a Python3 package

Seems you are using it as a python package:

It is somehow related to: https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/2532

```python
from os.path \
```

```python
from os.path import import, join, split
```

```python
from os.path import join, split
```

title: check-only false positive if file is missing closing newline
body:
`isort --check-only` will complain about import whitespace if the _file_ is missing a closing newline.

``` python
def test_strict_whitespace_no_newline(capsys):
    test_input = ('import os\n'
                  '\n'
                  'from django.conf import settings\n'
                  '\n'
                  'print(1)')
    SortImports(file_contents=test_input, check=True)
    out, err = capsys.readouterr()
    assert out == ''  # valid imports, but AssertionError
```


title: Incorrect grouping of from ... import ...

```py
from __future__ import division
from __future__ import print_function

import itertools
import logging
from abc import ABCMeta
from abc import abstractmethod

from six import add_metaclass

from six.moves import range  # <------------ This import is in the wrong group.

from treecat.structure import OP_OUT
from treecat.structure import OP_ROOT
from treecat.structure import OP_UP
from treecat.structure import TreeStructure
```

```
+from PyQt5.QtGui import QColor  # @UnresolvedImport pylint: disable=import \
+    -error,useless-suppression
+from PyQt5.QtGui import QFont  # @UnresolvedImport pylint: disable=import \
+    -error,useless-suppression

```

This is my call to isort:
```

    subprocess.check_call(
        [
            "isort",
            "-ot",
            "-m3",
            "-ns",
            "__init__.py"
        ] + target_files
    )

```

Splitting up "import-error" mid word is a mistake by itself as far as I am concerned, that's one word. And as a side node splitting "pylint: error-code,other-code" should also not be done, and it should be considered a word.

Thanks for the great tool,
Kay Hayen

title: Diff no longer shown when using `isort --check-only --diff` as of v4.2.9

title: --check-only false negative
body:
I've just ran into what seems to be a very peculiar bug:
Using `--check-only` together with a non-default line length causes isort to miss unsorted imports if the specified line length is longer than the longest import line **and** the imported names within a line are already sorted alphabetically.

Minimal example:
`x.py`:
```
import string
from hypothesis.stateful import Bundle, RuleBasedStateMachine, precondition, rule
from package.subpackage import ALongNameThatIsLong, ClassThatAlsoHasALongName, function
```

Correct:
```
~# isort --verbose --diff --check-only /tmp/x.py

ERROR: /tmp/x.py Imports are incorrectly sorted.
--- /tmp/x.py:before    2016-11-14 16:43:30
+++ /tmp/x.py:after     2016-11-14 16:44:32.028859
@@ -1,3 +1,7 @@
 import string
-from hypothesis.stateful import Bundle, RuleBasedStateMachine, precondition, rule
-from package.subpackage import ALongNameThatIsLong, ClassThatAlsoHasALongName, function
+
+from hypothesis.stateful import (Bundle, RuleBasedStateMachine, precondition,
+                                 rule)
+
+from package.subpackage import (ALongNameThatIsLong, ClassThatAlsoHasALongName,
+                                function)
```

Broken:
```
~# isort --verbose --diff --check-only --line-width 99 /tmp/x.py

SUCCESS: /tmp/x.py Everything Looks Good!
```

Just `--diff` without `--check-only` also works correctly:
```
~# isort --verbose --diff --line-width 99 /tmp/x.py

--- /tmp/x.py:before    2016-11-14 16:43:30
+++ /tmp/x.py:after     2016-11-14 16:53:00.779865
@@ -1,3 +1,5 @@
 import string
+
 from hypothesis.stateful import Bundle, RuleBasedStateMachine, precondition, rule
+
 from package.subpackage import ALongNameThatIsLong, ClassThatAlsoHasALongName, function
```

(Note that I've stripped the isort header to reduce noise)

title: Imports that wrap the maximum line length and contain comments are rendered incorrectly
body:
Consider:

``` python
from very_long_module_name import SuperLongClassName  #@UnusedImport -- long string of comments which wrap over
```

Running `isort` on it using `-m4` and forcing the use of parentheses renders this incorrect code:

``` python
from very_long_module_name import (
    SuperLongClassName  # @UnusedImport -- long string of comments which wrap over))))
```

(Note that `isort` added the `)` after the comment, which generated an syntactically invalid file).

title: aliases can cause isort to add backslashes even with multi_line_output=5
body:
When `multi_line_output` is set to 5 (which should result in parentheses), `isort` can still introduce backslashes. This can be seen in the Django project, for example, which [sets it to 5](https://github.com/django/django/blob/9a2a52558e080f109a27d40a033a135c9d0e7e50/setup.cfg#L16) and yet still has [the following](https://github.com/django/django/blob/9a2a52558e080f109a27d40a033a135c9d0e7e50/django/contrib/gis/db/backends/mysql/base.py#L1):

```
from django.db.backends.mysql.base import \
    DatabaseWrapper as MySQLDatabaseWrapper
```

some examples of missing packages:
- asyncio

- xmlrpc

title: force-sort-within-sections causes multi-line comments to be sorted
body:
If you have a multi-line comment before an import statement and run `isort --force-sort-within-sections` then the comment gets sorted.

E.g. sample.py

``` python
import re
import os.path

# report.py exists in ... comment line 1
# this file needs to ...  comment line 2
# it must not be ...      comment line 3
import report
```

`$ isort isort --force-sort-within-sections  -d sample.py`

```
import os.path
import re

# it must not be ...      comment line 3
# report.py exists in ... comment line 1
# this file needs to ...  comment line 2
import report
```

title: Windows filenames
body:
`isort` allows filenames to be specified in a config file, and the examples use unix path separators.

There is no translation between win32 filenames to unix filenames, so there is no way for the config to be valid for unix and win32 filenames.

title: isort on drone.io marks everything as third party
body:
[Wagtail](https://github.com/torchbox/wagtail) uses isort as part of its linting checks, which are automatically run on a [drone](https://drone.io/) instance. Drone clones git repos to a directory like `/drone/src/github.com/torchbox/wagtail` as part of its initialisation, before running the scripts. This causes an issue in isort 4.2.3 and above due to 9e384025d147ccd7b975e661b42cdb4f5363a918. isort looks in the path of the resolved Wagtail package and sees `src`, and assumes it is a third party package installed by pip. This is incorrect.

Sadly, it is not possible to reconfigure drone to clone the repo to somewhere else - cloning to a subdirectory of `/drone/src/` is a hard coded part of its git plugin.

I understand that supporting pip installed source packages is an important addition to isort, but the way it is implemented has broken every instance of isort running on Drone.

Is there a more robust way of checking if a package is a source install than the current method of just checking for `"src" in path`?

title: No way to turn off --order-by-type
body:
If invoked on the command line, --order-by-type can be passed and will set order_by_type to True , but settings.py already has an order_by_type default of True.

It's therefore not possible to turn this off.

Ideally this (and other boolean options) would have a --no-XXX option that reverses the sense (and so would allow you to override an .isort.cfg file in the case that it had already enabled a flag)

title: Single, too-long imports with Vertical Hanging Indent
body:
If I have a single import that exceeds line_length, isort will use the backslash to enforce the line-length. This feels wrong, as we've configured “Vertical Hanging Indent” for multi-lines.

We get:

```
from blub import /
    veeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeerylongname
```

where we'd rather have

```
from blub import (
    veeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeerylongname,
)
```

(We get this behavior correctly for long lines.)

Apart from being consistent, it'd also clarify and minimize the diff when a new import is added.
Finally, we'd like to adhere to PEP8:

```
“The preferred way of wrapping long lines is by using Python's implied line continuation
inside parentheses, brackets and braces. Long lines can be broken over multiple lines
by wrapping expressions in parentheses. These should be used in preference to using
a backslash for line continuation.”
```

Kudos to @dashmug for being a nit-picker.

title: isort is really slow when using --recursive since no way to efficiently exclude directories
body:
I've run isort against a repo and made some corrections, however to prevent regressions, I need to:
(a) Run on travis
(b) Make it quick for people to run locally before pushing, so they don't keep on getting burnt jobs on travis

To do this, I'd like to use:
`isort --recursive --check-only --diff .`

However this takes a long time to run (at least locally from inside the virtualenv in my vagrant environment, where the source is mounted using virtualbox shared folders).

ie: 36 seconds, compared to 5 seconds for running flake8 recursively against the same repo.

Annotating the isort file shows that it's spending a lot of time iterating over the `.git/` and `node_modules` directories, even though I have them listed in `--skip`.

Inspecting the source shows that isort doesn't use the contents of `--skip` (or `--skip-glob`) when it's constructing the list of files to scan. Instead it waits until after it's instantiated the `SortImports` instance to use them.

Compare this to pep8's implementation, where it skips a whole subdirectory if appropriate:
https://github.com/PyCQA/pep8/blob/b1bde9f2bbcad0f3c86960e58c7cb98ec0cbfd77/pep8.py#L1827-L1888

As a workaround, I'm having to hardcode the list of subdirectories, eg:
`isort --recursive --check-only --verbose *.py puppet/ tests/ treeherder/`
...which runs in 2.5 seconds.

Compared to the original, which takes 36 seconds - but is scanning the same set of Python files!

Please could a way be added to skip whole subdirectories in a performant manner? :-)

title: Line-length not properly enforced, leading to spurious check failures
body:
Using version 3.9.6 with `line_length=79`, I note the following behavior for this sample input file, `test.py`:

``` python
from .. import views
from ..views import (
    _a,
    _xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx as xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx)


def test():
    pass
```

```
> $ isort -c test.py
> $ echo $?
0
```

However, the check should fail because the `as` import line contains 80 characters. If I fix the line length, for example by wrapping before the `as`, isort claims the line violates the configured policy, and suggests an alternative which in fact violates the line length limitation:

```
+++ /Users/jgaren/Documents/dev/styleseat/test.py:after 2015-08-10 12:23:19.281534
@@ -1,5 +1,4 @@
 from .. import views
 from ..views import (
     _a,
-    _xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx
-    as xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx)
+    _xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx as xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx)


 def test():
```

If I then just give up, and try to have isort skip checking the line, I encounter yet another bug.

Input:

```
from .. import views
from ..views import (  # isort:skip
    _a,
    _xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx as xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx)


def test():
    pass
```

Output of --diff:

```
 from .. import views
+
 from ..views import (  # isort:skip
     _a,
     _xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx as xxxxxx_xxxxxxx_xxxxxxxx_xxx_xxxxxxx)
```

The suggested addition of a newline would not be correct, as it results in an extra import grouping.

title: The `--check-only` option enforces wrapping, which is not mentioned by the help text
body:
1) Clone https://github.com/mozilla/treeherder (revision 1c00ccf for reproducibility)
2) `pip install -r requirements/common.txt -r requirements/dev.txt`
3) `isort --check-only treeherder/webapp/api/urls.py`

Expected:
No errors shown - since all imports are correctly sorted, and `isort --help` says:

``` bash
  -c, --check-only      Checks the file for unsorted imports and prints them
                        to the command line without modifying the file.
```

Actual:

``` bash
~/treeherder $ isort --check-only treeherder/webapp/api/urls.py
ERROR: /home/vagrant/treeherder/treeherder/webapp/api/urls.py Imports are incorrectly sorted.
```

Presumably since the wrapping is being changed:

``` bash
~/treeherder $ isort --diff treeherder/webapp/api/urls.py
--- /home/vagrant/treeherder/treeherder/webapp/api/urls.py:before       2015-08-10 18:12:02.451898
+++ /home/vagrant/treeherder/treeherder/webapp/api/urls.py:after        2015-08-10 18:31:24.116318
@@ -6,8 +6,9 @@
 from rest_framework import routers

 from treeherder.webapp.api import (artifact, bug, job_log_url, jobs, logslice,
-                                   note, performance_artifact, performance_data,
-                                   projects, refdata, resultset)
+                                   note, performance_artifact,
+                                   performance_data, projects, refdata,
+                                   resultset)

 # router for views that are bound to a project
 # i.e. all those views that don't involve reference data
```

The help text should either be adjusted to say something like:
`Checks the file for unsorted imports or mis-wrapped imports`
...or else `--check-only` should only show errors if the actual order was wrong. (The latter would probably be more useful for me personally, but I understand it may be more surprising for other people. Perhaps a separate `--dont-change-wrapping` option might help, which could be used for --check-only plus all of the other modes? My use-case is running check-only mode on Travis to ensure people don't regress the import order, but I'm not too fussed about the wrapping style).

Using isort 4.0.0 with Python 2.7.10 on Ubuntu 14.04.

Many thanks :-)

title: Seen producing "from __future__ import importprint_function, print_function"
body:
When asking isort to add

```
from __future__ import print_function
```

to a file that already has

```
from __future__<tab>import print_function
```

(for whatever reason, though valid)
the result will be

```
from __future__ import importprint_function, print_function
```

which no longer executes.

For a demo on the shell:

```
isort -a 'from __future__ import print_function' --diff 203.py ; echo ; od -c 203.py
--- 203.py:before
+++ 203.py:after
@@ -1 +1 @@
-from __future__    import print_function
+from __future__ import importprint_function, print_function

0000000   f   r   o   m       _   _   f   u   t   u   r   e   _   _  \t
0000020   i   m   p   o   r   t       p   r   i   n   t   _   f   u   n
0000040   c   t   i   o   n  \n
0000046
```

title: semi colon interpreted as comma
body:
I have a file with a single line in it:
`import pdb; pdb.set_trace()`

When I run isort on the file, it changes the behaviour of the code:

```
--- /opensource/captainhook/test/files/pdb_errors.py:before
+++ /opensource/captainhook/test/files/pdb_errors.py:after
@@ -1 +1,3 @@
-import pdb; pdb.set_trace()
+import pdb.set_trace
+
+import pdb;
```

Having 2 statements on one python line is not pep8 friendly, but I think that isort should format it either:

```
--- /opensource/captainhook/test/files/pdb_errors.py:before
+++ /opensource/captainhook/test/files/pdb_errors.py:after
@@ -1 +1,3 @@
-import pdb; pdb.set_trace()
+import pdb
+
+pdb.set_trace();
```

Or maybe it should leave it alone as it is not really an import reordering that is taking place.

title: On Ubuntu 12.04 isort thinks that `binascii` is 3rd party, and that `cv2` is stdlib
body:
- `binascii` is part of the python stdlib but `isort` treats it as a 3rd party module.
- `cv2` is from `apt-get install python-opencv`, but `isort` treats it as part of the python stdlib.

This doesn't happen on my mac (`isort` behaves correctly); it only happens on my [Travis CI job](https://travis-ci.org/drothlis/stb-tester/builds/25047971) which is running Ubuntu 12.04.

What information can I gather to help you diagnose this?

title: Kate plugin no longer showing up after installation in Kate 3.13
body: In the latest version of Kate (3.13) with Pate V2.0 installed the isort plugin no longer shows up as an available plugin after installation into one of Pate's lookup paths.

title: Imports followed by comment followed by function don't receive enough space (according to pep8)
body:
(TL;DR: I _think_ comments should be ignored when determining what the "next" thing in a file is after imports)

`pep8` is happy with the following file:

``` py
import sys


# This is a comment
def foo():
    pass
```

Running `isort` on it removes one of the newlines between the import and the comment, which makes `pep8` unhappy.

The `lines_after_imports` setting lets us work-around this (which is good :thumbsup:), but it means that we _always_ end up with two spaces, even in the cases where `pep8` would be happy with only 1.

For example, `pep8` _is_ happy with the single space in this case:

``` py
import sys

# This is a comment
wibble = 'bar'
```

P.S. Thanks for all your hard work making a great tool!

title: order_by_type may have caused unexpected issues
body:
Following the changes for allowing `order_by_type` (thanks for that by the way)

I get the following diff

``` diff
-import StringIO

-from subprocess import Popen, PIPE, STDOUT
+from subprocess import PIPE, Popen, STDOUT
```


title: Imports added using -a get appended for files without imports
body:
I have a file in my code base that looks like this:

```
"""Module docstring"""

class MyClass(object):
    pass
```

I try to run this:

```
isort -a "from __future__ import print_function"
```

Afterwards the file looks like this:

```
"""Module docstring"""

class MyClass(object):
    pass

from __future__ import print_function
```

Since `__future__` imports need to be at the top of the file, this is invalid syntax.

```

```

```
from .node import nullrev

```

I expect you need a check to see if the comment is already there.

title: indent string config adds quotation marks to hanging indents
body:
When I run (the current 2.6.1 from PyPI) isort using the command line options like this:

```
$ isort --multi_line=2 src/**/*.py
```

my imports get formatted like this:

```
from third_party import  lib1, lib2, lib3, \
    lib4, lib5, lib6
```

When I try to use the config file to configure indent permanently like this:

```
$ cat .isort.cfg
[settings]
# [...]
indent='    '
```

my source gets polluted with quotation marks like this:

```
from third_party import  lib1, lib2, lib3, \
'    'lib4, lib5, lib6
```

Seems like the string from the configuration file gets copied without removing the quotation marks.

title: Don't install unnecessary dependencies

title: Newlines in input file
body:
The check feature gives a wrong output, if there are newlines in the insert line of the input file. 

For example:

```
from lib import (
  some_object,
  some_other_object)
```

Here is a test for this problem.

``` python
from mock import patch

def test_check_newline_in_imports():
    test_input = "from lib1 import (\n  sub1, sub2\n  sub3)"
    SortImports.file_path = ''  # Add file_path to Class
    with patch('__builtin__.print') as mock_print:
        SortImports(file_path=False, file_contents=test_input, check=True)
    assert 'SUCCESS' in mock_print.call_args[0][0]
```

title: isort silently writes output to the current directory, even if run on a different path
body:
It seems like the tool always writes the result into the current directory, which is pretty unexpected. I think you should provide an --inplace option or fail explicitly if you don't know where to save the result.

Currently for the unsuspecting newcomer it seems that the tool does nothing when run on a different path.
